SEC. 101. Extension of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, and by sections 510, 1108(b), and 1925 of such Act, shall continue through March 31, 2004, in the manner authorized for fiscal year 2002. Grants and payments may be made for carrying out such activities during the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004 at the level provided for the first two quarters of fiscal year 2002. Amendments are made for supplemental grants for population increases in certain states. Amendments are made to supplemental grants for population increases in certain states, contingency fund, and maintenance of effort under the Social Security Act. Changes include updating dates from 2003 to 2004 and adding provisions for fiscal year 2001 and 2005. SEC. 102 extends the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations. SEC. 201 allows disclosure of return information for income contingent repayment of student loans. TITLE II--TAX PROVISIONS

SEC. 201. Disclosure of return information for income contingent repayment of student loans extended to December 31, 2004.

SEC. 202. Extension of Internal Revenue Service user fees under new section 7528. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees on requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters. Fees will vary based on categories, taking into account time and difficulty, and must be paid in advance. The Secretary can provide exemptions and reduced fees as deemed appropriate. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees on requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters. Fees must be paid in advance and exemptions can be provided as deemed appropriate. During the fifth plan year of a pension benefit plan's existence, or at the end of any remedial amendment period within the first 5 plan years. The text discusses definitions and rules related to pension benefit plans, eligible employers, and highly compensated employees. Eligible employers must have at least one non-highly compensated employee participating in the plan. The determination of an eligible employer under subparagraph (B) for a pension benefit plan is based on the date of the request. Any request under subparagraph (B) is not considered for determining average fees charged. The average fee charged under the program must meet a minimum amount as specified in the table provided. The IRS imposes various user fees for different rulings and determinations, ranging from $200 to $350. No fee is charged for requests made after December 31, 2004. Additionally, a new section on Internal Revenue Service user fees is added to the Code. The Revenue Act of 1987 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. Fees collected under the Internal Revenue Code must be approved by an appropriations Act. Amendments apply to requests made after the enactment date. COBRA fees are extended to March 31, 2004. Medicare cost-sharing provisions are addressed in Title IV. SEC. 301 extends COBRA fees to March 31, 2004. SEC. 401 extends Medicare cost-sharing for certain qualifying individuals. Section 1902(a)(10)(E)(iv) of the Social Security Act is amended to extend the sunset provision to March 2004 for Medicare cost-sharing. Section 1933(c) is also amended to increase the total amount available for allocation for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the total number of individuals described in section 1902(a)(10)(E)(iv) in the State should be increased. A special rule for the first quarter of 2004 states that a State shall select qualifying individuals and provide assistance according to the provisions in effect for calendar year 2003. In 2004, a State shall select qualifying individuals and provide assistance according to the provisions in effect for calendar year 2003, with a total allocation amount of $100,000,000. SEC. 402 extends the provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments. The provision equalizing urban and rural Medicare inpatient hospital payments is extended until March 31, 2004, with the option for the Secretary of Health and Human Services to delay implementation if necessary. The Secretary may delay implementing amendments to comply with Congressional intent until November 1, 2003, with adjustments for fiscal year 2004 to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. The Secretary may delay implementing amendments until November 1, 2003, with adjustments for fiscal year 2004 to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. The application of the amendments will not affect payment rates for subsequent periods after September 30, 2004. The Secretary is not required to issue regulations or provide notice in the Federal Register for the administration of these provisions. The Secretary has the authority to implement amendments without the need for rulemaking or notice in the Federal Register. There is no review allowed for any delays or determinations made by the Secretary under this authority.
